entry.title: Getting this Blog Working with IPython Notebook
entry.summary:
I'm using IPython Notebook 1.1.0. in my work. I wanted to post some IPython stuff on a blog and found it rather difficult to do so on Blogger so I started digging around for an alternative. From what I can tell, static blog generators are the way to go for this sort of thing if you're geek enough to deal with the setup and ongoing operation. It's not as simple as Wordpress or Blogger but shouldn't be too bad if you're comfortable with Python and GitHub and whatnot. Basically, I decided that I'm geek enough.

I started out following the directions I found here. However, this stuff changes pretty fast and it seems like things are a bit different now. The changes specified here are no longer needed. I installed pelican using the development version cloned from GitHub. The version installed by pip didn't work with the GitHub version of liquid tags. It took me a while to figure that out. Hopefully I can save someone else some time or at least save myself some time when I go to replicate this on my laptop.

So, assuming you've got ipython 1.1.0 already, I guess the proceedure is:

  1. Get pelican by doing git clone https://github.com/getpelican/pelican.git, then going to where pelican was cloned (cd pelican) and typing python setup.py install. Use sudo python setup.py install if you have permission problems.

  2. I'm using the Octopress template. To use that, go clone it from GitHub. Then do sudo pelican-themes -i /path/to/pelican-octopress-theme/.

  3. Go clone pelican-plugins and follow the directions in the liquid tags readme.

entry.title: Stats book chapter 5
entry.summary:
What's this all about?¶

I'm working on getting a better grasp of some statistical concepts that I need for my research. I'm using Experimental Design and Data Analysis for Biologists (referred to as 'the book' from here on). At the same time, I want to learn how to perform the analyses I'm learning about using open source Python. This is the IPython Notebook I put together for some of the topics in Chapter 5 of the book. If you have a bit of familiarity with Python, this should help you figure out some statistics. ...maybe...

Import the Python libraries I'm planning to use.

In [1]: 
from scipy import stats
import pandas as pd

Replicating figure 5.3¶

Here's how to create a plot kind of like figure 5.3 from the book. I'm just focusing on how to recreate this type of plot for the moment so I'll just produce some random data to mess with.

In [2]: 
x = np.arange(1,101,0.5)
rnds = np.random.rand(200) + np.random.randint(-20,20,200)
y = x + rnds
xrand = x + np.random.rand(200) + np.random.randint(-30,30,200)

I'm going to use matplotlib's GridSpec to layout the plot.

In [3]: 
import matplotlib.gridspec as gspec
gs = gspec.GridSpec(2,2,width_ratios=[6,1],height_ratios=[1,4])

subplot(gs[0])
boxplot(xrand,vert=False)
axis('off')
subplot(gs[2])
scatter(xrand,y)
# scaled would be nice (it makes the plot more square)
# but it only changes the axses of the scatter so that 
# the box plots don't line up anymore. I'm too lazy to
# figure out a fix right now.
#axis('scaled') 
subplot(gs[3])
boxplot(y)
axis('off')
Out[3]:
(0.5, 1.5, -20.0, 120.0)
In [4]: 
# polyfit will give the slope and intercept
m,b = polyfit(xrand,y,1)
yp = polyval([m,b],xrand)
scatter(xrand,y)
plot(xrand,yp)
print "m=%.3f, b=%.3f" % (m,b)

m=0.732, b=14.468

Using stats.linregress is better because it returns more information. Here's the list of returns from the SciPy Documentation:

slope : float
    slope of the regression line
intercept : float
    intercept of the regression line
r-value : float
    correlation coefficient
p-value : float
    two-sided p-value for a hypothesis test whose null hypothesis is
    that the slope is zero.
stderr : float
    Standard error of the estimate
In [5]: 
stats.linregress(xrand,y)
Out[5]:
(0.73229548154182211,
 14.467543254662019,
 0.79650004813236441,
 3.8618341322441897e-45,
 0.039506060540604897)

So \(r^2\) would be:

In [6]: 
stats.linregress(xrand,y)[2]**2
Out[6]:
0.63441232667485881

Here's another way to get the correlation coefficient.

In [7]: 
corrcoef(xrand,y)
Out[7]:
array([[ 1.        ,  0.79650005],
       [ 0.79650005,  1.        ]])

Box 5.1¶

Now we'll try to do Box 5.1 from Experimental Design and Data Analysis for Biologists. I'm going to use the actual data used in the book (it's available online) and demonstrate how you'd reproduce the plots in the book (more or less) using Python.

In [27]: 
# get the data
xmas_island = pd.read_csv('http://www.zoology.unimelb.edu.au/qkstats/chpt5/green.csv')
# put the data from the two sites in their own data frames for ease of use
DS = xmas_island[xmas_island.SITE=='DS']
LS = xmas_island[xmas_island.SITE=='LS']
# have a look at the LS data frame
LS.head() # the head method will display the first five rows
Out[27]:
SITE QUADNUM TOTMASS BURROWS
8 LS 1 4.36 38
9 LS 2 4.01 37
10 LS 3 3.33 27
11 LS 4 2.63 18
12 LS 5 4.46 41

Pearson, Spearman, and Kendall statistics and \(P\) values are super easy to calculate:

In [9]: 
# Pearson assumes bivariate normal distribution
ls_pearson_r, ls_pearson_p = stats.pearsonr(LS.TOTMASS, LS.BURROWS)
# The next two are rank based so don't assume normal distribution
# They should work for any monotonic relationship
ls_spearman_r, ls_spearman_p = stats.spearmanr(LS.TOTMASS, LS.BURROWS)
ls_kendall_tau, ls_kendall_p = stats.kendalltau(LS.TOTMASS, LS.BURROWS)

I'll stick the values in a pandas data frame so they display in a nice little table thing:

In [10]: 
ls_d = { 'Statistic': pd.Series([ls_pearson_r,ls_spearman_r,ls_kendall_tau], index=['Pearson','Spearman','Kendall']),
         'P Value'  : pd.Series([ls_pearson_p,ls_spearman_p,ls_kendall_p], index=['Pearson','Spearman','Kendall']) }
ls_df = pd.DataFrame( ls_d )
ls_df
Out[10]:
P Value Statistic
Pearson 0.000735 0.881955
Spearman 0.001791 0.851068
Kendall 0.003798 0.719147

The Pearson correlation is the same thing as the correlation coefficient \(r\), right? It looks like it. (remember, \(r\) is the 3rd value spit out by linregress)

In [11]: 
stats.linregress(LS.TOTMASS,LS.BURROWS)
Out[11]:
(9.4152096922052131,
 -3.1495512013031899,
 0.88195494383269679,
 0.00073499375761430276,
 1.7789638248707702)

Now I'm going to just more or less reproduce figure 5.3 from the book. I may want to do something similar for my own work so it seems worth doing.

In [12]: 
figure(figsize=[10,5])
gs = gspec.GridSpec(2,4,width_ratios=[3,.5,3,.5],height_ratios=[1,4])

gs0 = subplot(gs[0])
boxplot(LS.TOTMASS.values,vert=False)
axis('off')
subplot(gs[4])
scat_ls = scatter(LS.TOTMASS.values,LS.BURROWS.values)
# That didn't work and I can't be bothered to figure out why right now.
#scat_ls.axes.text(scat_ls.axes.get_ylim()[1]-1, scat_ls.axes.get_xlim()[0]+0.5, 'LS')
gs5 = subplot(gs[5])
boxplot(LS.BURROWS.values)
# The axes weren't staying lined up so I'm going to explicitly size them
gs0.axes.set_xlim( scat_ls.axes.get_xlim() )
gs5.axes.set_ylim( scat_ls.axes.get_ylim() )
axis('off')

gs2 = subplot(gs[2])
boxplot(DS.TOTMASS.values,vert=False)
axis('off')
subplot(gs[6])
scat = scatter(DS.TOTMASS.values,DS.BURROWS.values)
gs7 = subplot(gs[7])
bpgs7 = boxplot(DS.BURROWS.values)
gs2.axes.set_xlim( scat.axes.get_xlim() )
gs7.axes.set_ylim( scat.axes.get_ylim() )
axis('off')
Out[12]:
(0.5, 1.5, 20.0, 90.0)

Replicating Figure 5.17¶

In [13]: 
# get the data into a pandas data frame
peake = pd.read_csv('http://www.zoology.unimelb.edu.au/qkstats/chpt5/peake.csv')

Take a look at some of the data to see what's there. (using the HTML method from IPython just makes the formating a bit nicer)

In [14]: 
from IPython.display import HTML
HTML( peake.head().to_html() )
Out[14]:
AREA SPECIES INDIV LAREA LSPECIES LINDIV RESID1 PREDICT1 RESID2 PREDICT2 RESID3 PREDICT3 RESID4 PREDICT4
0 516.00 3 18 2.712650 0.477121 1.255273 -7.196363 10.196363 -0.296087 0.773208 -166.608318 184.608318 -0.433547 1.688820
1 469.06 7 60 2.671228 0.845098 1.778151 -3.165416 10.165416 0.087871 0.757227 -122.918638 182.918638 0.123915 1.654237
2 462.25 6 57 2.664877 0.778151 1.755875 -4.160926 10.160926 0.023375 0.754776 -125.673502 182.673502 0.106941 1.648934
3 938.60 8 100 2.972481 0.903090 2.000000 -2.474981 10.474981 0.029630 0.873460 -99.820473 199.820473 0.094243 1.905757
4 1357.15 10 48 3.132628 1.000000 1.681241 -0.750929 10.750929 0.064750 0.935250 -166.886842 214.886842 -0.358225 2.039466

The full data set has way more columns than I need because I want to calculate that stuff rather than just plot it so I'll make a data frame that has just the data I want.

In [15]: 
arsp = pd.DataFrame({"Area": peake.AREA, "Species": peake.SPECIES, "Indiv": peake.INDIV} )
arsp.head()
Out[15]:
Area Indiv Species
0 516.00 18 3
1 469.06 60 7
2 462.25 57 6
3 938.60 100 8
4 1357.15 48 10

In order to get the residuals, it looks like I have to use numpy's polyfit method with full=True.

In [16]: 
np.polyfit(arsp.Area, arsp.Species, 1, full=True)
Out[16]:
(array([  6.59295373e-04,   9.85616668e+00]),
 array([ 325.0644671]),
 2,
 array([ 5.22007139,  1.42910565]),
 5.5511151231257827e-15)

Well, crap. That second array is supposed to be the residuals but there's just a single value there. That's not what I was expecting. I probably misread the documentation or something. Fortunately, there seems to be another way using the statsmodels package. I'm going to be following this example except that I'm using statsmodels version 0.4.3 so I won't be using the \(R\) style api. There's a good IPython notebook demo here.

In [17]: 
import statsmodels.api as sm
sm.version.version
Out[17]:
'0.5.0.dev-49d386f'

The example in the documentation shows "model=sm.OLS(Y,X)" I'd sort of expect X first, then Y but whatever. According to In [8] of this, I have to add a column of ones to allow the calculation of the intercept. I don't quite grasp why but I guess it's forcing through the origin if I don't? I need to dig through the statsmodels documentation a bit more.

In [18]: 
X = sm.add_constant( arsp.Area, prepend=True )
model = sm.OLS(arsp.Species, X)
results = model.fit()

results is an object with a crap-ton of attributes and methods. Here's the documentation for it. results.resid will return a pandas data series with all of our residuals.

In [19]: 
results.resid
Out[19]:
0    -7.196363
1    -3.165416
2    -4.160926
3    -2.474981
4    -0.750929
5    -2.025533
6    -0.967745
7    -0.033859
8     4.106564
9    -3.480241
10    0.226557
11    1.208861
12   -1.141363
13    1.209402
14    6.523814
15    7.214803
16    0.437242
17    4.111320
18    5.463147
19    5.020502
20   -3.907719
21    0.759630
22   -1.149149
23   -2.752100
24   -3.075518
dtype: float64

Now I'm going to try to come up with a function for making plots like Figure 5.17 from the book.

In [20]: 
def fancy_plot(xarr,yarr,xlabel,ylabel):
    # generate all the OLS crap
    X = sm.add_constant( xarr, prepend=True )
    mod = sm.OLS(yarr, X)
    res = mod.fit()
    
    # generate predicted values for residual plot
    # first get slope and intercept from results
    intercept, slope = res.params
    # define a function based on my regression
    f = lambda x: intercept + slope * x
    # generate predicted values for my values of X
    predicted = f( xarr )
    
    # produce smoother line
    # note that the x and y values are supplied in 
    # reversed order from what I'd expect.
    smoo = sm.nonparametric.lowess(yarr,xarr,frac=0.5,return_sorted=False)
    # FYI, that works in statsmodels version 0.5+ but not in 0.4.3.
    
    figure(figsize=[15,8])
    gs = gspec.GridSpec(2,3,width_ratios=[4.5,1,4.5],height_ratios=[1,4])
    
    gs0 = subplot(gs[0])
    boxplot(xarr,vert=False)
    axis('off')
    subplot(gs[3])
    scat = scatter(xarr,yarr,marker='o',facecolors='none',s=50)
    scat.axes.plot(xarr,smoo)
    scat.axes.set_ylabel(ylabel) #('Number of Species')
    scat.axes.set_xlabel(xlabel) #('Clump Area ($m^2$)')
    gs5 = subplot(gs[4])
    boxplot(yarr)
    # The axes weren't staying lined up so I'm going to explicitly size them
    gs0.axes.set_xlim( scat.axes.get_xlim() )
    gs5.axes.set_ylim( scat.axes.get_ylim() )
    axis('off')
    
    subplot(gs[5])
    smoo2 = sm.nonparametric.lowess(res.resid,predicted,frac=0.5,return_sorted=False)
    scat_resid = scatter(predicted,res.resid,marker='o',facecolors='none',s=50)
    scat_resid.axes.plot(predicted,smoo2)
    scat_resid.axes.set_ylabel('Residual')
    scat_resid.axes.set_xlabel('Predicted Value')
In [21]: 
# see if it works
fancy_plot(arsp.Area.values, arsp.Species.values, 'Clump Area ($m^2$)', 'Number of Species')

Awwwww yeah. That worked but we can see that the fit is pretty crap. results.summary() will confirm that.

In [22]: 
results.summary()
Out[22]:
OLS Regression Results
Dep. Variable: Species R-squared: 0.687
Model: OLS Adj. R-squared: 0.673
Method: Least Squares F-statistic: 50.44
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2013 Prob (F-statistic): 3.10e-07
Time: 14:11:19 Log-Likelihood: -67.538
No. Observations: 25 AIC: 139.1
Df Residuals: 23 BIC: 141.5
Df Model: 1
coef std err t P>|t| [95.0% Conf. Int.]
const 9.8562 1.044 9.441 0.000 7.697 12.016
Area 0.0007 9.28e-05 7.102 0.000 0.000 0.001
Omnibus: 0.886 Durbin-Watson: 1.000
Prob(Omnibus): 0.642 Jarque-Bera (JB): 0.893
Skew: 0.367 Prob(JB): 0.640
Kurtosis: 2.434 Cond. No. 1.56e+04

Now we'll do the same thing with \(\log_{10}\) transformed data.

In [23]: 
fancy_plot(log10(arsp.Area.values), log10(arsp.Species.values), 'Log Clump Area', 'Log Number of Species')

Well do it again (not so efficient in terms of computing but this only takes a second) with \(\log_{10}\) values to see the summary table.

In [24]: 
Xlog = sm.add_constant( log10(arsp.Area), prepend=True )
model_log = sm.OLS(log10(arsp.Species), Xlog)
results_log = model_log.fit()
results_log.summary()
Out[24]:
OLS Regression Results
Dep. Variable: Species R-squared: 0.819
Model: OLS Adj. R-squared: 0.812
Method: Least Squares F-statistic: 104.4
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2013 Prob (F-statistic): 5.11e-10
Time: 14:11:20 Log-Likelihood: 23.332
No. Observations: 25 AIC: -42.66
Df Residuals: 23 BIC: -40.23
Df Model: 1
coef std err t P>|t| [95.0% Conf. Int.]
const -0.2734 0.138 -1.975 0.060 -0.560 0.013
Area 0.3858 0.038 10.215 0.000 0.308 0.464
Omnibus: 10.887 Durbin-Watson: 1.781
Prob(Omnibus): 0.004 Jarque-Bera (JB): 9.296
Skew: -1.196 Prob(JB): 0.00958
Kurtosis: 4.790 Cond. No. 27.4

Right. So. I'm a bit confused as to why my summary is giving the const value as -0.2734. I think that's supposed to be the intercept and box 5.4 of the book lists that as being 1.270. Oh well, I can plot the crap out of things now at least.

I tried the same thing in \(R\) and got the same values so I'm not sure what's going on. There's another way to do it in python as well:

In [25]: 
slope, intercept, r_value, p_value, std_err = stats.linregress(log10(arsp.Area.values),log10(arsp.Species.values))
print "slope=%.3f, intercept=%.3f" % (slope,intercept)

slope=0.386, intercept=-0.273

Well there are the same values again so I don't know what the deal is. At any rate, the main point of this exercise was for me to be able to produce those plots and the lowess smoother stuff.

entry.title: Why does this blog exist?
entry.summary:
I already have a blog so why have another? That other blog was set up so that friends and family could follow our progress across the pacific as we sailed to New Zealand. This blog is intended for a completely different audience. If you followed the other blog and liked it, there's no reason to suspect that you'll like this one. In fact there's every reason to suspect you'll find this boring and/or incomprehensible.

This blog is intended as a combination of research notebook, collaboration outreach, and public service (for a rather narrow audience). I'm working on my PhD at the University of Auckland's Leigh Marine Laboratory but I have a background in programming. My current work is focused on creating open source software tools for remote sensing, data analysis, and quantitative accuracy assessment. I do a bit of field work (and have done heaps more in the past) but, generally speaking, I'm up to my elbows in Python code for GIS and statistics while my colleagues here at the lab are up to their elbows in fish guts and other more traditional aspects of marine biology. As I fight with my data, subject it to painful statistical analysis, and learn how to use new tools, I hope to document my progress with this blog. I'll be able to refer back to when I've forgotten how I did something. Other people who're trying to do something similar could benefit (as I have from many similarly nerdy blogs) and, if I'm lucky, this blog may help me make contact with others working on similar tasks.

So I apologize in advance to my friends and family who might see what I post here. You're probably not going to like it much. If, on the other hand, you're one of the rare individuals who finds this sort of thing interesting and/or useful please feel free to contact me. I would find it gratifying to know that someone's been helped and I'd love to collaborate on some projects.
